Estimated ODA pledged to Ukraine (USD mi:
43.1>>25 February: The Czech government approved the provision of urgent humanitarian aid to Ukraine to the total of CZK 300 million (approx. US $13.1 million). These funds focused primarily on the provision of essentials to internally displaced people in Ukraine.

2 March: The Czech Republic provided medical equipment to Ukraine from the stocks of the Ministry of Defence and the State Material Reserves Administration to the total of CZK 20.9 million and CZK 85.3 million respectively (a total of approx. US $4.6 million).

6 April: The government approved a humanitarian donation of CZK 14 million (approx. US $0.6 million) to supply durable food for internally displaced people in Ukraine.

1 May: The Ministry of Interior donated CZK 25 million (approx. US $1.1 million) from the Assistance on the Ground program to the ICRC, which will provide medical care in Ukraine. A further CZK 25 million of funding went to UNHCR, but this is excluded due to a specific focus on Moldova.

7 May: Foreign Minister Jan Lipavský has stated an additional EUR 18 million (approx. US $19.3 million) in humanitarian assistance to Ukraine.

6 July: The Czech Republic has sent an additional cargo of medical aid to the Ukrainian Ministry of Health worth CZK 100 million (approx. US $4.4 million).

Estimated ODA pledged to Ukraine (USD mi:
2,147.0>>5 May: President Ursula von der Leyen announced new aid package of €200 million to support displaced people in Ukraine

30 May: As part of the April 9th 'Stand Up for Ukraine' pledging event, the EC pledged a total of EUR 1 billion, consisting of EUR 600 million million for internally displaced people in Ukraine, via the repurposing of existing funds and humanitarian assistance, and EUR 400 million for Ukrainian refugees in frontline Member States via repurposed and new home affairs funds. The EU also allocated a further EUR 45 million in humanitarian funding for projects in Ukraine. We exclude EBRD's EUR 1 billion loan to cover the needs of people displaced by the invasion pledged at this event.

30 May: Approximatley EUR 14 million has been sent to Ukraine via the rescEU medical stockpiles based in Germany, HUngary and the Netherlands.

21 July: Ukraine recieved EUR 120 million in the form of grants as part of a State and Resilience Building Contract (SRBC), to support societal and state resilience in Ukraine. This grant came with a EUR 1.2 billion loan of Macro Financial Assistance, which we have excluded due to insufficient detail to calculate a grant equivalent measure.

21 July: EUR 330 million has been provided to an emergency support programme that helps to secure access to basic goods and services, such as to education, healthcare and food in Ukraine.

21 July: Currently, EUR 335 million has been made available for humanitarian aid projects to help civilians affected by the war in Ukraine (excluding EUR 13 million for Moldova).
